narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I improved my Chinese vocabulary, as well as my writing and oral presentation skills. This course uses higher-level vocabulary since it is focused on current affairs...which is pretty different from colloquial Chinese used at home or casually among friends.
This was a really great Chinese class for learning how to speak, read, and write more formal Chinese. I feel like my Chinese skills greatly improved.
Sharpened my Chinese speaking, reading, and writing
learned to communicate and write formal Chinese news, including listening to official news videos and conversing with advanced level Chinese phrases
Sense of formal written Chinese, grammar, and vocabulary that's actually useful!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Zhou Laoshi is an excellent professor and has designed this course well. The topics that we cover in class are interesting and relevant (climate change/environment, elder care/demographics, public health, as well as topics currently in the news). Furthermore, assignments (weekly writing assignments, Quizlets, presentations every few weeks) give ample opportunities to practice the vocabulary students have learned. Lastly, I enjoyed the amount of customizability in this course; Zhou Laoshi is very clear that this course is largely dependent on the student's willingness to learn, and to this end he gives flexibility in what vocabulary words individual students wish to learn or which topics they wish to focus on for presentations. 

Weakness: My only criticism of the course is that the final project might be better as a live oral presentation rather than a recorded, mock news studio format. I found myself spending a lot of time editing the video and getting shots right, which, while a good exercise in videography, did not directly help my Chinese skills and instead took some time away from my other courses. Additionally, I think an additional presentation would have helped me improve my extemporaneous speaking skills even further.

Strengths: improvement-focused, grounded in current events, fun!
Weaknesses: a lot of work, excessive amounts of work at some points in the semester

The strength of this course is definitely Zhou Laoshi - he cares deeply about his students and every class with him is just made better with his comforting presence! The one weakness that comes to mind may be lack of speaking opportunities - there is a lot of emphasis on writing in this course but I personally would've preferred more opportunities to speak casually in class (outside of formal oral presentations)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: For the most part, the course was handled well online. I'm not sure what more can be done short of having class in person :)
Our class was fairly small, so the Zoom format worked well. Our homework was all conducive to the remote format as well.
I think this course succeeded with online learning, especially with breakout rooms giving the students more opportunities to interact.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you hope to take your Chinese skills to the next level. This course is especially helpful for those who can speak Chinese well in a casual setting, but are looking to develop vocabulary related to business and politics.
Yes absolutely. If you are interested in an advanced Chinese language class that doesnt follow the mold of typical language classes (textbook readings, vocab quizzes, etc.) this is the class for you.

Yes! Zhou Laoshi is the best. This course is a lot of work, between readings, vocab, twice weekly fake news stories, oral presentations, and other assignments. But Zhou Laoshi is very generous with grading and really just wants to see you improve. It is really fun to apply Chinese knowledge to real world news stories. The vocab you learn in this course is very useful for reading about and discussing current events.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student!! You learn a lot about current events - especially with the pandemic this year - and a lot of the vocab is relevant to daily conversation in real life.
Yes! Chill class where you get as much as you put in
